pageProps.body:
Complex Exponentiation

To extend exponentiation to complex numbers, we use the Taylor series definition of exponentiation:

Definition (Exponential function). Define ez=∑n=0∞xzz!e^z=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^z}{z!}ez=∑n=0∞​z!xz​, which can be verified to satisfy the known properties of exponentiation, such as eaeb=ea+be^{a}e^{b}=e^{a+b}eaeb=ea+b. We assume that this sum converges for all complex numbers z∈Cz \in \mathbb{C}z∈C.

Similarly, we would like to extend the trigonometric functions to the complex realm, where a geometric definition fails due to the budding, unhinged insanity that underlines the words "an angle of 39+46πi39+46\pi i39+46πi degrees":

Definition (Complex sine and cosine). Define

sin⁡z=∑n=0∞(−1)nx2n+1(2n+1)!=x−x33!+x55!+...\sin z = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^{n}\frac{x^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!} = x-\frac{x^3}{3!}+\frac{x^5}{5!}+...sinz=n=0∑∞​(−1)n(2n+1)!x2n+1​=x−3!x3​+5!x5​+...

and

cos⁡z=∑n=0∞(−1)nx2n(2n)!=1−x22!+x44!−...\cos z = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^{n}\frac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!} = 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-...cosz=n=0∑∞​(−1)n(2n)!x2n​=1−2!x2​+4!x4​−...

From the two above results, we obtain a very important formula throughout all of math.

Theorem (Euler's formula).

eiz=cos⁡z+isin⁡ze^{iz}=\cos z + i\sin zeiz=cosz+isinz

It almost feels like I should be wearing a suit and tie before doing this. We also note that any complex number can thus be written in terms of a complex exponential, as its modulus-argument form (r,θ)(r,\theta)(r,θ) suggests it can be written as

z=r(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ)=reiθz=r(\cos \theta + i\sin \theta)=re^{i\theta}z=r(cosθ+isinθ)=reiθ

which allows us to state that multiplication between two complex numbers z1=r1eiθ1z_1=r_1e^{i\theta_1}z1​=r1​eiθ1​ and z2=r2eiθ2z_2=r_2e^{i\theta_2}z2​=r2​eiθ2​ requires the multiplication of their moduli and addition of their arguments.

Complex Logarithms

Definition (Complex logarithm). Define the complex logarithm ω=ln⁡z\omega = \ln zω=lnz as the number which satisfies eω=ze^\omega = zeω=z.

If zzz is a complex number z=reiθz=re^{i\theta}z=reiθ, then we have eω=reiθe^{\omega} = re^{i\theta}eω=reiθ and thus ln⁡1r=iθ−ω\ln \frac{1}{r} = i\theta - \omegalnr1​=iθ−ω and ω=ln⁡reiθ=iθ+ln⁡r\omega = \ln re^{i\theta} = i\theta +\ln rω=lnreiθ=iθ+lnr. (also, ln⁡ab=ln⁡a+ln⁡b\ln ab = \ln a + \ln blnab=lna+lnb gets us here.)

Definition (Complex powers). Define zαz^\alphazα for complex zzz as eαln⁡ze^{\alpha\ln z}eαlnz, where we insist that the argument used for zzz is −π<θ<π-\pi < \theta < \pi−π<θ<π, the principal argument.

This gives rise to

Theorem (De Moivre's Theorem).

cos⁡nθ+isin⁡nθ=(cos⁡θ+isin⁡nθ)n.\cos n\theta + i\sin n\theta =(\cos \theta + i\sin n\theta)^n.cosnθ+isinnθ=(cosθ+isinnθ)n.

This can be proven by induction; it is functionally identical to stating that eniθ=(eiθ)ne^{ni\theta}=(e^{i\theta})^neniθ=(eiθ)n, which is obvious over the reals but not so obvious over complex numbers.
